item.title: Climbing stairs is as effective as walking 10,000 steps, says new study - The Times of India
item.description:
Climbing stairs is as effective as walking 10,000 steps, says new study

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Times of India

This article discusses a recent study that reveals climbing stairs provides the same health benefits as walking 10,000 steps daily, challenging common perceptions about exercise.

  • Climbing stairs is shown to enhance cardiovascular health.
  • The study suggests that stair climbing may offer a time-efficient alternative to lengthy walks.
  • Experts recommend incorporating more stairs into daily routines for improved fitness.
“Integrating stair climbing into your day can significantly boost physical activity levels,” said the study's lead researcher.

This study underscores the importance of diverse physical activities and encourages individuals to find practical ways to enhance their exercise regimens.

item.title: Researchers find concerning mutation in H5N1 bird flu found in Canadian teen - The Times of India
item.description:
Researchers find concerning mutation in H5N1 bird flu found in Canadian teen

Date: 2023-10-25 Source: Health News Daily

This article discusses the discovery of a significant mutation in the H5N1 bird flu virus in a Canadian teenager, raising concerns about its potential implications for public health.

  • The mutation may increase the virus's transmissibility among mammals.
  • Health officials are monitoring the situation closely given the pandemic implications.
  • The teenager is reported to be recovering, but the case has prompted further investigation.
“This mutation could pose a serious risk if it adapts to human-to-human transmission.” - Lead Researcher

The findings highlight the need for vigilance regarding influenza virus mutations and emerging health threats.

item.title: 8 ways to reduce uric acid in your body - The Times of India
item.description:
8 Ways to Reduce Uric Acid in Your Body

Publication Date: Jan 1, 2025 | Source: Times of India

Excess uric acid can lead to gout, kidney stones, and inflammation in joints. Here are eight effective strategies to manage uric acid levels:

  • Stay hydrated by drinking plenty of water.
  • Limit purine-rich foods, such as red meat and seafood.
  • Maintain a healthy weight.
  • Include cherries and Vitamin C-rich foods in your diet.
  • Avoid sugary beverages and processed foods.
  • Opt for low-fat dairy products.
  • Avoid alcohol, especially beer and spirits.
“Managing uric acid levels is crucial for overall health.”

This article emphasizes the importance of diet and hydration in keeping uric acid in check, which can prevent serious health issues like gout.

item.title: Simple tips to shed belly fat in 2025 - The Times of India
item.description:
Simple Tips to Shed Belly Fat in 2025

Publication Date: 2025

Source: Unknown

This article provides practical tips for individuals looking to reduce belly fat effectively in the upcoming year. It covers various strategies and lifestyle changes that can help facilitate weight loss.

  • Focus on dietary changes, such as reducing sugar intake.
  • Incorporate regular exercise, including both cardio and strength training.
  • Stay hydrated and manage stress levels through mindfulness practices.
  • Consider meal prepping to maintain a healthy diet consistently.
  • Seek support from community groups or wellness programs.
"Small changes can lead to significant results over time."

By implementing these simple strategies, individuals can work towards achieving their weight loss goals effectively in 2025.

item.title: Why older adults remain highly vulnerable to diarrhoea, particularly in South Asia - The Indian Express
item.description:
Why older adults remain highly vulnerable to diarrhoea, particularly in South Asia

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: The Indian Express

A recent study published in The Lancet Infectious Diseases reveals that older adults in South Asia continue to be highly vulnerable to diarrhoeal diseases despite a global decrease in mortality. This demographic faces the highest mortality rates along with children under five.

  • Elderly Vulnerability: Those aged 70 years and older in South Asia had the highest mortality rate globally, with 476 deaths per 100,000 population.
  • Regional Disparities: High-income countries reported fewer than one death per 100,000 children under five, while sub-Saharan Africa has over 150 deaths in the same age group.
  • Declining DALYs: The burden of diarrhoeal diseases decreased from 186 million in 1990 to 59 million in 2021.

Why older adults are at higher risk in South Asia

Dr. Manisha Arora explains that older adults are susceptible due to a decline in immune function and pre-existing health conditions that complicate hydration during diarrhoeal episodes. “Older adults often face a dilemma during diarrhoea,” she notes, highlighting the challenges of hydration management.

Tackling the crisis

Dr. Arora emphasizes a multifaceted approach to reduce mortality rates among the elderly in South Asia:

  1. Improve Access to Clean Water and Sanitation: Essential for preventing diarrhoeal diseases.
  2. Strengthen Healthcare Infrastructure: Timely diagnosis and treatment are critical.
  3. Promote Vaccinations: Vaccines can significantly help in reducing disease incidence.
  4. Education and Awareness: Importance of hydration and early treatment should be communicated.
  5. Focus on Elderly Care: Interventions for fluid replacement and management of comorbidities are crucial.

While global mortality rates from diarrhoeal diseases have declined, the situation for older adults in South Asia demands urgent attention. As Dr. Arora points out, “Addressing dehydration, improving healthcare access, and promoting preventive measures are key.”

item.title: FDA starts testing raw cheese for bird flu - The Times of India
item.description:
FDA Starts Testing Raw Cheese for Bird Flu

Date: October 2023 | Source: FDA Press Release

The FDA has initiated testing of raw cheese samples for the presence of bird flu as part of ongoing food safety efforts.

  • The tests aim to ensure the safety of dairy products amidst rising concerns about animal-borne diseases.
  • This initiative is part of a broader strategy to monitor and mitigate the risks associated with foodborne pathogens.
  • Producers are being notified and asked to comply with testing requirements.
“Our goal is to ensure public health and safety by actively monitoring potential risks in food products,” said a spokesperson for the FDA.

By implementing these measures, the FDA hopes to reassure consumers and maintain the integrity of the food supply.

item.title: Healthy start: 25 dietitian-approved tips to build better eating habits in 2025 - The Globe and Mail
item.description:
Healthy Start: 25 Dietitian-Approved Tips for Better Eating Habits in 2025

Publication Date: January 2025 | Source: The Globe and Mail

This January, many individuals are setting new year resolutions aimed at improving their diet and health. The article presents 25 practical tips from dietitians to help build better eating habits over the coming year.

  • Prioritize protein at breakfast to support various bodily functions.
  • Keep a food diary to enhance self-awareness about eating habits.
  • Drink a large glass of water before meals to help prevent overeating.
  • Increase fibre intake with a focus on breakfast foods.
  • Emphasize heart-healthy fats and reduce saturated fat.
  • Practice sustainable eating by reducing food waste.
  • Eat slowly to allow your body to register fullness.
  • Incorporate vegetables into at least two meals a day.
  • Add fermented foods like yogurt and kefir to your diet.
  • Use smaller plates to help control portion sizes.
  • Snack on fruit to increase nutrient and antioxidant intake.
  • Include green tea, known for its health benefits, in your daily routine.
  • Eat leafy greens regularly to support health and cognitive function.
  • Plan meals a week in advance to ensure nutritional balance.
  • Flavor meals with herbs and spices to boost nutrients without added salt.
  • Include plant-based meals several times a week.
  • Add ground flaxseed for its health benefits.
  • Include orange vegetables for their beta carotene content.
  • Replace sugary drinks with healthier options.
  • Cut back on daily calories to prevent gradual weight gain.
“Small changes can lead to significant health benefits over time.”

These tips are designed to be implemented gradually, ensuring sustainability and easier adaptation to healthier lifestyles as the year progresses.

item.title: Researchers are questioning if ADHD should be seen as a disorder | Mint - Mint
item.description:
Reevaluating ADHD: From Disorder to Neurodiversity

Date: April 20, 2023 | Source: The Economist

ADHD, once thought of as a childhood disorder, is now increasingly diagnosed in adults as well. With improved understanding of women's experiences and the challenges of a distracted world, more people are seeking and benefiting from diagnoses and medication. However, some experts argue that ADHD may not be a disorder but rather a part of neurodiversity.

  1. ADHD diagnosis is evolving, with better recognition of symptoms in women and girls.
  2. Medication can be life-changing for those with severe symptoms but has risks and may not be a long-term solution.
  3. Non-pharmaceutical interventions, such as supportive environments and cognitive tools, can help manage ADHD symptoms.
  4. ADHD diagnosis is subjective and relies on self-reported symptoms, leading to varied estimates of prevalence.
  5. Scientists are exploring a 'transdiagnostic' approach to help individuals with cognitive, behavioral, and emotional difficulties without relying on diagnostic labels.
"It has become more accepted in the past ten years that it is not a single biological entity." - Edmund Sonuga-Barke, neuroscientist at King’s College London

In conclusion, while ADHD diagnoses are rising and medication can be beneficial, the understanding of ADHD as a disorder is evolving, with some experts advocating for a shift towards considering it a part of neurodiversity.

item.title: Heart attack risk: How winter holidays may increase cardiac problems? - India.com
item.description:
Heart Attack Risk: How Winter Holidays May Increase Cardiac Problems

Publication Date: Not specified   Source: India.com

The winter holiday season, although a time for celebration, can paradoxically lead to an increase in heart attack risks. Indulgences and decreased physical activity during this festive period can result in serious health effects.

Key Points

  • Dietary Changes: Indulgence in rich foods and high sodium during the holidays can raise blood pressure and cholesterol levels.
  • Increased Stress Levels: Holiday pressures can elevate stress hormones, increasing heart rate and blood pressure.
  • Cold Weather Effects: Cold conditions can raise blood pressure and workload on the heart, posing risks for individuals with heart conditions.
  • Physical Inactivity: Sedentary lifestyles during the holidays can lead to poor cardiovascular health.
  • Neglecting Health Monitoring: Skipping medications and health routines can exacerbate potential heart issues.

By minding dietary habits, managing stress, staying active, and prioritizing health, individuals can enjoy festivities while minimizing heart risks.

item.title: How to calm your mind with breathing, according to science - The Washington Post
item.description:
How to Calm Your Mind with Breathing Techniques According to Science

Date: January 1, 2025 Source: The Washington Post

This article discusses the benefits of breathwork practices and how slowing our breath can help alleviate stress and improve mood.

  • Conscious and intentional breathing can lead to a sense of calm.
  • Research indicates that breathwork influences our emotional state and behavior.
  • Effective breathing techniques can be utilized to manage stress levels.
“Research shows that breathwork practices and slowing our breath can alleviate stress and improve mood by harnessing the often subtle but profound influence our breathing has on how we think, feel and behave.”

Overall, incorporating breathwork into daily routines can promote better mental health and emotional well-being.

item.title: From improving skin texture to promote hair health: 7 reasons to have cumin seeds everyday - India.com
item.description:
7 Health Benefits of Consuming Cumin Seeds Daily

Publication Date: Not specified Source: India.com

This article outlines seven health benefits of incorporating cumin seeds into your daily diet, highlighting their nutritional advantages.

  • Rich in Iron: High iron content supports red blood cell production, preventing anemia.
  • Aids Weight Loss: Cumin seeds boost metabolism, aiding in effective weight management.
  • Promotes Hair Health: Nutrients in cumin seeds prevent hair fall and support hair growth.
  • Improves Digestion: Rich in antioxidants and dietary fiber, aiding digestion and preventing bloating.
  • Enhances Skin Texture: Antibacterial properties help fight skin infections and promote a radiant glow.
  • Boosts Immunity: Loaded with Vitamin C and antioxidants that strengthen the immune system.
  • Regulates Blood Sugar Levels: Helps manage blood sugar levels, reducing the risk of diabetes.
“Cumin seeds are a powerhouse of nutrients that benefit various aspects of health.”

Incorporating cumin seeds into your daily diet can lead to numerous health benefits, making it a valuable addition to your meals.

item.title: How to reduce blood sugar: Nutritionist shares a type of food that has 'an enormous effect on lowering blood sugar' levels - GB News
item.description:
Nutritionist Shares a Type of Food That Lowers Blood Sugar

Publication Date: Not Provided Source: GB News

Managing blood sugar levels is challenging in a landscape full of processed carbohydrates. Nutritionist Mark Gilbert suggests building meals around protein to stabilize blood sugar.

  • Focus on consuming protein before starchy or sugary foods.
  • Reducing serving sizes of starchy and sugary foods is crucial.
  • Decreasing visceral fat can help normalize organ function and improve blood sugar levels.
  • Avoid processed carbohydrates to prevent overeating.
  • Other recommended foods for lowering blood sugar include cinnamon, apple cider vinegar, and bitter melon.
“The overall key is to reduce the visceral fat, allowing the organs to function normally again.” - Mark Gilbert

By maintaining consistent dietary changes, individuals can anticipate decreased blood sugar levels over time.

item.title: 10 Weight-Loss Tips That Actually Work, According to Dietitians - EatingWell
item.description:
10 Weight-Loss Tips That Actually Work, According to Dietitians

Publication Date: N/A Source: N/A

Losing weight is often framed as a simple equation: eat less and move more, but sustainable weight loss requires finding strategies that work for you. Here are 10 expert-backed tips for effective weight loss.

  • Start Small: Set small, achievable goals to build momentum.
  • Have a Long-Term Mindset: Focus on steady, manageable progress over time.
  • Make the Healthy Choice the Easy One: Prepare your environment for success with healthy options.
  • Pump Up the Protein: Incorporate protein into meals to help curb cravings.
  • Focus on Fiber: Eat high-fiber foods to regulate appetite.
  • Stop the Negative Self-Talk: Be kind to yourself and celebrate small wins.
  • Don’t Fear Snacking: Choose nutritious snacks to prevent hunger.
  • Find Movement You Enjoy: Choose activities that you look forward to doing.
  • Practice Mindful Eating: Be present and listen to your body's cues during meals.
  • Get Support: Build a support system to help maintain your weight loss.
“Even imperfect progress is still progress.”

The article emphasizes that lasting change comes from embracing small, sustainable steps and being kind to yourself throughout the weight loss journey.

item.title: 10 foods to start your New Year on a healthy note - Recipes
item.description:
10 Foods to Start Your New Year on a Healthy Note

Publication Date: Jan 1, 2025

Source: Times of India

The new year brings with it fresh opportunities to embrace a healthier lifestyle. Incorporating nutrient-dense foods into your diet can help you kick-start the year with energy and vitality. Here are 10 foods to help you begin 2025 on a healthy note.

  • Avocado: Rich in healthy fats for heart health.
  • Quinoa: A protein-packed alternative to rice.
  • Spinach: High in iron, calcium, and vitamins.
  • Chia Seeds: Full of omega-3 fatty acids and fiber.
  • Almonds: Great source of vitamin E and antioxidants.
  • Sweet Potatoes: Nutrient-rich and high in fiber.
  • Lentils: Offers protein and fiber at a low cost.
  • Blueberries: Loaded with antioxidants.
  • Salmon: Rich in omega-3 fatty acids.
  • Greek Yogurt: Keeps your gut healthy and full of protein.
“The new year brings with it fresh opportunities to embrace a healthier lifestyle.”

This list of foods can play a crucial role in enhancing your overall health as you commence the New Year.

item.title: 91 & counting: US sees sudden spike in Norovirus cases; what's it, how it spreads & precaution one must take - Firstpost
item.description:
91 & counting: US sees sudden spike in Norovirus cases; what's it, how it spreads & precaution one must take

Publication Date: December 2025 Source: CDC

The highly contagious norovirus has raised alarms in the United States, with a significant surge in cases reported in early December.

  • 91 cases of norovirus were reported in the first week of December.
  • This is more than double the highest weekly count recorded over the past three years.
  • Norovirus primarily spreads through contaminated food, water, and surfaces.
  • Symptoms include vomiting, diarrhoea, and dehydration; they typically appear 1-2 days after exposure.
  • Maintaining hydration is crucial during the acute phase of the illness.
“Norovirus is the leading cause of foodborne illness in the US, accounting for 58% of all such cases.”

This sudden spike in norovirus cases underscores the importance of hygiene and food safety, particularly in crowded communities during the winter months.

item.title: Here’s a resolution for 2025: Good habits that boost your brain health - Central Florida Public Media (previously WMFE)
item.description:
Boost Your Brain Health: New Year's Resolutions for 2025

Published January 1, 2025 at 6:00 AM EST

As Floridians make New Year's resolutions, the Alzheimer's Association suggests focusing on good habits that boost brain health. An updated analysis in The Lancet reveals that addressing 14 modifiable risk factors could delay or prevent nearly half of dementia cases.

  • Obesity
  • Unmanaged diabetes
  • High blood pressure
  • Physical inactivity
  • Lack of education
  • Hearing loss
  • Smoking
  • Depression
  • Excessive alcohol consumption
  • Brain injury
  • Air pollution
  • Social isolation
  • Vision loss
  • High cholesterol

To mitigate these risks, the Alzheimer's Association promotes the '10 Healthy Habits for Your Brain': staying mentally active, maintaining education, exercising, protecting the head, avoiding smoking, eating healthily, maintaining a healthy weight, sleeping well, managing high blood pressure, and diabetes.

The Lancet's recommendations for society include improving education, access to hearing aids, treating depression, promoting helmet use, encouraging exercise, reducing smoking, controlling blood pressure, managing cholesterol, maintaining a healthy weight, reducing alcohol consumption, promoting social engagement, and reducing air pollution.

The article highlights the importance of these habits and the need for societal changes to reduce dementia risk.

item.title: Dengue cases see spike in Gujarat, contrary to seropositivity trends - Gujarat Samachar
item.description:
Spike in Dengue Cases in Gujarat Amid Decreasing Seropositivity Rates

Publication Date: 2024

Source: Gujarat Samachar

Gujarat reported a spike in dengue cases in 2024 despite a drop in the seropositivity rate, indicating effective disease control measures.

  • 7,820 dengue cases reported in 2024, up from 7,222 in 2023.
  • Seropositivity rate decreased from 4.7% in 2023 to 3.5% in 2024.
  • 2.21 lakh serum samples tested in 2024; 1.49 lakh in 2023.
  • State government purchased 170,000 rapid test kits for quick diagnosis.
  • 492 vector control teams monitored 2,460 areas to control the spread of disease.
  • Samples sent to medical facilities to identify circulating dengue virus types.
“Despite the increase in cases, the seropositivity rate has decreased from 4.7% in 2023 to 3.5% in 2024.”

This situation highlights the importance of continued surveillance and control measures, as the health department aims to manage the spread of dengue effectively.

item.title: Breakthrough links inflammation to depression’s causes - Telangana Today
item.description:
Inflammation-Depression Link: Breakthrough Paves Way for Personalized Treatments

Date & Source: Updated On - 1 January 2025, 06:02 PM, Source: Telangana Today

New Delhi: Scientists have uncovered a significant link between inflammation and depression, a discovery that could revolutionize our understanding of mental health and pave the way for personalized treatments.

The groundbreaking research by Raz Yirmiya from Hebrew University of Jerusalem suggests that the activation and suppression of the immune system can trigger depressive symptoms, highlighting the need for tailored treatment approaches.

  1. The study found that exposure to stress activates inflammatory processes in the brain, which can lead to depression.
  2. Yirmiya's team identified several promising therapeutic targets by combining molecular techniques with behavioral studies.
  3. The research suggests potential for developing personalized treatments based on individual inflammatory profiles.
"My overarching aim is to harness the extensive knowledge from my research and others to accelerate the development of novel antidepressant therapeutics targeting inflammatory processes." - Raz Yirmiya

Yirmiya's work is part of a larger series by Genomic Press that highlights the people behind today's most influential scientific ideas.

item.title: Are monk fruit sugar and stevia risky? Try these healthier natural sweeteners - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Are Monk Fruit Sugar and Stevia Risky? Try These Healthier Natural Sweeteners

Publication Date: December 30, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

This article discusses the potential health risks associated with monk fruit sugar and stevia, highlighting the dangerous ingredient erythritol and presenting safer natural alternatives.

  • Monk fruit sugar and stevia may contain erythritol, which is linked to increased risks of blood clotting.
  • Coconut sugar is introduced as a lower glycemic alternative, rich in minerals but should be consumed in moderation.
  • Dates and date syrup are highlighted for their nutrient density and health benefits.
  • Maple syrup offers flavor and minerals but should also be used sparingly, especially by diabetics.
  • Agave nectar is presented as a vegan preferred option but needs moderation due to high carbs.
  • Allulose, a rare sugar found in figs, is noted for low blood sugar impact and potential fat loss benefits.
“The hidden risk: Stevia and monk fruit sugar often contain erythritol, linked to doubled risks of blood clotting. Time to rethink your sweetener.”

The article emphasizes the need for consumers to reconsider their sweetener choices in light of potential health risks. It encourages exploring healthier alternatives that offer nutritional benefits.

item.title: Bird flu, brain rot and booze – the health issues you’ll be hearing more about in 2025 - The Guardian
item.description:
Bird flu, brain rot and booze – the health issues you’ll be hearing more about in 2025

Publication Date: [Insert Date Here] | Source: The Guardian

As we approach 2025, there are multiple public health concerns poised to gain attention, ranging from the ongoing threat of bird flu to the mental health implications of social media and the risks associated with alcohol consumption.

Several key topics are outlined for the upcoming year:

  • Bird flu cases, especially H5N1, pose a growing concern with potential human-to-human transmission.
  • Research highlights the positive effects of exercise on mental health and disease prevention.
  • Increased regulation of social media use among adolescents is anticipated due to its negative impact on mental health.
  • New evidence emerges regarding the harmful effects of alcohol on health, emphasizing the need for responsible consumption.
  • The rise of weight-loss drugs like Ozempic and their associated risks will likely lead to caution surrounding their use.
  • Advancements in cervical cancer elimination and malaria vaccination programs are bringing hope for significant health improvements.
“A child dies every minute from malaria and a woman dies from cervical cancer every two minutes.”

In conclusion, as we move into 2025, awareness and regulation concerning both emerging health threats and beneficial practices are crucial for improving public health outcomes.

item.title: Vitamin B12 deficiency causes tingling in hands and feet, low haemoglobin levels - India Today
item.description:
Vitamin B12 Deficiency Causes Tingling in Hands and Feet, Low Haemoglobin Levels

Published On: Jan 1, 2025 | Source: India Today

A recent study conducted in Mumbai revealed the significant impact of vitamin B12 deficiency on physical and neurological health, with a higher prevalence observed in men.

  • The two-year study included 180 patients aged 18 to 70 with low haemoglobin and vitamin B12 levels.
  • Common health issues reported among participants included high blood pressure (33.3%) and diabetes (25%).
  • The most frequently reported symptom was fatigue, affecting 66.7% of patients.
  • Neurological symptoms, such as tingling and numbness, were reported by over half of the participants.
  • After six weeks of treatment, participants showed significant improvements in haemoglobin levels and overall blood health.
“Proper vitamin B12 supplementation can effectively reverse health issues, improving blood health and neurological symptoms.”

The findings underscore the necessity of routine screening for vitamin B12 deficiency, particularly among older adults and vegetarians, to prevent long-term health complications.

item.title: 7 Unhealthy Practices That You Must Immediately Stop Following In 2025 For Your Overall Health - TheHealthSite
item.description:
7 Unhealthy Practices to Stop in 2025 for Overall Health

Date & Source: 2025-01-01, The HealthSite

Introduction: As we step into 2025, it's crucial to reflect on our daily habits and identify areas that may be harming our health. Discontinuing certain old practices and adopting healthier habits can improve our overall quality of life, increase energy levels, and reduce the risk of serious health conditions.

  1. Consuming excessive sugar: High sugar intake can lead to obesity, diabetes, and heart disease. Limit daily intake to less than 25 grams (6 teaspoons) and opt for natural sources like fruits and vegetables.
  2. Ignoring sleep schedule: Poor sleep habits can disrupt your body's internal clock, leading to fatigue, mood disorders, and weakened immune system. Aim for 7-9 hours of sleep each night and establish a consistent sleep pattern.
  3. Skipping breakfast: A big dietary mistake, skipping breakfast can lead to nutrient deficiencies, low energy, and overeating later in the day. Start your day with a balanced breakfast that includes protein, whole grains, and healthy fats.
  4. Using electronic devices before bedtime: Pre-bedtime use of phones and laptops can interfere with sleep patterns and make it difficult to fall asleep. Avoid using electronic devices at least an hour before bedtime and opt for relaxing activities like reading or meditation.
  5. Not staying hydrated: Inadequate hydration can lead to headaches, fatigue, and digestive problems. Drink at least 8-10 glasses of water each day and limit sugary drink intake.
  6. Sitting for long periods: Prolonged sitting can increase the risk of chronic diseases like heart disease, diabetes, and obesity. Take regular breaks to stand up, stretch, move around, and aim for at least 30 minutes of physical activity every day.
  7. Not managing stress: Chronic stress can lead to anxiety, depression, and a weakened immune system. Practice stress-reducing techniques like deep breathing, yoga, or meditation, and take breaks to relax and recharge.

Conclusion: By recognizing and abandoning these unhealthy practices, we can take the first step towards a healthier, happier life in 2025.
